questions.question_text: What does the deployer do in a Search Head Cluster (SHC)? (Select all that apply.)

discussion.content: A and C
A and C

comments.content:
"You use the deployer to deploy configuration updates only. You cannot use it for initial configuration of the search head cluster or for version upgrades to the Splunk Enterprise instances that the members run on."
From the same link you shared. Only A is correct

"Types of updates that the deployer handles
These are the specific types of updates that require the deployer:
All non-search-related updates, even those that can be configured through the CLI or Splunk Web, such as updates to indexes.conf or inputs.conf."

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/7.3.2/DistSearch/PropagateSHCconfigurationchanges#Types_of_updates_that_the_deployer_handles

discussion.content:
"The deployer has these main roles:

It handles migration of app and user configurations into the search head cluster from non-cluster instances and search head pools.
It deploys baseline app configurations to search head cluster members.
It provides the means to distribute non-replicated, non-runtime configuration updates to all search head cluster members".

Selected Answer: A
Only A is correct.
B is just to confuse you by the word "bootstrap"
C is incorrect, because "You do not use the deployer to distribute search-related runtime configuration changes."

comments.content: You have answer C written incorrectly. Answer C is written as "Distributes non-search related and manual configuration file changes" and that is exactly what the deployer is built for. The answer is A and C.

discussion.content: A and C, you can make manual config changes to your Search ahead cluster, like make your web.conf file to allow https for web ui

Only A seems correct. 
It deploys baseline app configurations to search head cluster members.
It provides the means to distribute non-replicated, non-runtime configuration updates to all search head cluster members. Does not copy any manual changes to other SHC
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.1.0/DistSearch/PropagateSHCconfigurationchanges
A and D.

choices.C: Distributes non-search related and manual configuration file changes.
choices.B: Bootstraps a clean Splunk install for a SHC.
choices.D: Distributes runtime knowledge object changes made by users across the SHC.

questions.question_text: When adding or decommissioning a member from a Search Head Cluster (SHC), what is the proper order of operations?

discussion.content: My answer is A

Selected Answer: A
I think the question should have been, "When adding a new or decommissioned member to a Search Head Cluster (SHC), what is the proper order of operations?". Page 185 of the latest Splunk Cluster Administration PDF.

Selected Answer: A
A. 1. Delete Splunk Enterprise, if it exists. 2. Install and initialize the instance. 3. Join the SHC.

Selected Answer: A
Question and answers do not fit well, however among the given answers A is the best.

Selected Answer: A
It should be A, however A is only for adding a new member, not decommissioning... there's steps you have to do to remove a member from a search head cluster that would be done prior to A.

Selected Answer: A
pg 197 | Cluster
A is correct
A Always use new Instances

choices.A: 1. Delete Splunk Enterprise, if it exists. 2. Install and initialize the instance. 3. Join the SHC.
choices.C: 1. Initialize cluster rebalance operation. 2. Remove master node from cluster. 3. Trigger replication.
choices.B: 1. Install and initialize the instance. 2. Delete Splunk Enterprise, if it exists. 3. Join the SHC.
choices.D: 1. Trigger replication. 2. Remove master node from cluster. 3. Initialize cluster rebalance operation.

choices.A: splunk cmd btool inputs list | tail
choices.B: splunk cmd btool check inputs layer

questions.question_text: When troubleshooting monitor inputs, which command checks the status of the tailed files?

discussion.content:

This test is BS how would someone pass this without this website .... Answer is C

C. curl https://serverhost:8089/services/admin/inputstatus/TailingProcessor:FileStatus

reference:

https://community.splunk.com/t5/Getting-Data-In/How-to-find-status-of-files-being-monitored/m-p/136792
C, page 65, troubleshooting

choices.B: Only if there are fewer than twelve concurrent users.
choices.D: Only if CPU and memory resources are significantly under-utilized.
choices.C: Only if running Splunk Enterprise version 6.6 or later.
choices.A: Only if disk IOPS is at 800 or better.

questions.question_text: When should multiple search pipelines be enabled?

discussion.content: D - Page 140 Architecting Splunk

Selected Answer: D
Answer D - https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.1.0/Capacity/Parallelization
Ans D -You can set multiple search pipelines if you have unused CPU/memory resources
D - https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.2.6/Indexer/Pipelinesets
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/7.0.2/Indexer/Pipelinesets

Selected Answer: D
D. Inverted index (.tsidx) Size is ~10-110% of raw data

D. Inverted index (.tsidx) files may consume the most disk space within an index bucket.

Inverted index files (.tsidx) are used in search engines to map terms to the documents or records in which they occur. These files contain a list of all unique terms in the index bucket and the locations of those terms in the indexed documents. Because they contain information about every term in the index, they can be quite large, especially for large datasets with many unique terms.

Rawdata, bloom filter, and metadata files (.data) typically take up less space than inverted index files. Rawdata files contain the actual data that is being indexed, while bloom filters are used to quickly identify which terms are likely to be present in a document. Metadata files contain additional information about the indexed documents, such as timestamps or author names.

B should be the answer. 

D may be wrong because there's no mention for inverted index being a tsdix.

Selected Answer: D
My answer is D

Selected Answer: D
Page 41 architecting Splunk

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D Final answer

comments.content: Yes, D is the answer. Source's on the 7th page: https://conf.splunk.com/files/2016/slides/tco-savings-through-storage-reduction.pdf

discussion.content: My Answer is D
